#Text=Paint an Aluminum Boat
#Text=If you want to give your aluminum boat a fresh coat of paint , there are some simple steps you can take to ensure the paint job looks great .
#Text=Sand the boat to create an even surface , and use soap and water to wash any dirt off .
#Text=Prime the boat so that the paint adheres to the surface easily , and you can spray , roll , or brush the paint onto the boat .
#Text=Applying a clear coat once the paint is completely dry will help protect all of your work .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Cleaning and Sanding the Boat
#Text=Lay plastic or paper over your workspace to prevent paint stains .
#Text=Find a spot , ideally outdoors , where you can paint your boat without damaging any other surfaces or items .
#Text=Spread out a large piece of plastic or several layers of paper to cover your entire work surface .
#Text=Choose a spot far away from any buildings , cars , or other things that might get damaged if paint accidentally gets on them .
#Text=Place the boat off of the ground to easily reach it .
#Text=You ’ll need to be able to paint all around the boat , so it should be set above the ground .
#Text=You can prop the boat up on something like sawhorses so that you can paint it more easily .
#Text=Sand the boat to remove old paint and create a smooth surface .
#Text=You can use an electric sander or regular pieces of sandpaper , whichever you have access to .
#Text=Use 40 or 80-grit sandpaper , sanding the inside of the boat before flipping it over and sanding the exterior .
#Text=Sanding the boat may result in small scratches in the aluminum , which is normal .
#Text=Wash the boat using soap and water .
#Text=Dip a hard-bristled brush in soapy water and use it to scrub off any sanding debris or leftover dirt .
#Text=Rinse the entire boat off with a hose , or you can power wash the boat if desired .
#Text=If the boat is super dirty , dip a towel or sponge in a cleaning solution and scrub it over any tough spots .
#Text=Dry the boat thoroughly .
#Text=The boat will need to be completely dry before it can be primed or painted .
#Text=Use a towel to dry the boat quickly , or let the boat air dry .
#Text=If it ’s sunny outside , opt for letting the boat air dry .
#Text=This will ensure that there are n’t any damp spots when you go to paint it .
#Text=Applying Primer
#Text=Find a primer that ’s suitable for metal surfaces .
#Text=Priming the boat will help protect the surface while also helping the paint stick to the boat .
#Text=Look for a self-etching primer that works on aluminum at a home improvement store or online .
#Text=You can mix a little bit of paint thinner with the primer to help conceal any tiny scratches in the metal , if desired .
#Text=Oil-based primers are often used when painting aluminum .
#Text=Apply the primer to the interior of the boat in an even layer .
#Text=You can spray the primer on , or you can use a roller or paint brush .
#Text=Apply it in an even , thin layer to the inside of the boat , making sure to get all of the cracks and corners .
#Text=If you ’re spraying the primer onto the boat , make sure the area is well-ventilated .
#Text=Allow the primer to dry before priming the exterior .
#Text=How long the primer takes to dry depends on the specific type and the environment in which it ’s drying , but wait several hours before flipping the boat over .
#Text=Prime the outside of the boat just as you did the inside , spreading the primer in an even layer .
#Text=Leave the entire boat to dry for 10-12 hours , or overnight .
#Text=This gives the primer enough time to completely dry before you start adding paint .
#Text=If you primed the boat outside , you can leave it outside to dry as long as the weather is supposed to remain clear .
#Text=If it ’s supposed to rain , bring the boat into a garage or shed , making sure to still keep it propped up .
#Text=Painting the Boat
#Text=Apply your desired water-resistant paint to the boat ’s interior .
#Text=You can choose any color that you like , just make sure that the paint is made to withstand water .
#Text=Use a sprayer , paint brush , or roller to apply the paint to the inside of the boat , just as you did with the primer .
#Text=Make sure you paint all of the seams in the boat well , as these tend to chip the easiest .
#Text=Let the paint dry before painting the exterior of the boat .
#Text=Check the instructions on the container of paint to see how long it takes the paint to dry , but it 's best to leave the boat untouched for at least 10 hours .
#Text=Once the interior coat is dry , flip the boat over carefully and start painting the outside .
#Text=Use slow , even strokes when painting and cover the exterior evenly .
#Text=Let the first coat of paint dry completely before you paint a second coat , if necessary .
#Text=Paint a second coat of the paint , if desired .
#Text=Once the first coat is dry , you can apply a second coat of paint to the interior and exterior , using the same painting tools .
#Text=A second coat will help ensure the paint job looks even , and it will provide another layer of protection for your boat .
#Text=Leave the boat to dry overnight before adding a clear coat .
#Text=Set the boat up overnight ( inside , if the weather will be poor ) so that the paint has time to dry completely .
#Text=Use a roller or paint brush to spread the clear coat over the interior and exterior of the boat using thin , even strokes .
#Text=Leave the boat propped up until it dries .
#Text=You can find a protective clear coat that will help prevent scratches and weather-related damage at a home improvement store or online .
#Text=Once the clear coat is dry , it should help protect your aluminum boat for up to 10 years .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If there are areas of the boat you do n't want to be painted , cover them with painter 's tape or newspaper .
